author: @statquest
text: NOTE: A lot of people ask "What happens when the original collection of measurements is not representative of the underlying distribution?" It's important to remember that a confidence interval is not guaranteed to overlap the true, population mean. A 95% CI means that if we make a ton of CIs using the same method, 95% of them will overlap the true mean. This tells us that 5% of the time we'll be off. So yes, a sample that is totally bonkers is possible, but rare. Understanding this risk of making the wrong decision, and managing it, is what statistics is all about. Also, at 5:55 I say there are up to 8^8 combinations of observed values and possible means, but this assumes that order matters, and it doesn't. So 8^8 over counts the total number of useful combinations and the true number is 15 choose 8, which is 6435 (for details on this math, see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiset#Counting_multisets )  Support StatQuest by buying my book The StatQuest Illustrated Guide to Machine Learning or a Study Guide or Merch!!! https://statquest.org/statquest-store/

author: @brettclark3885
text: At 6:40 when you start to discuss the 95% CI; I think there will be a lot of people who wont understand the subtlety of this distribution. You have created a distribtuion of 'statsitics'; in this case the mean. So, as you would appreciate you have derived the "sampling distribution' of the mean, from which the standard deviation = the standard error of the mean and the 95% CI calcaution is trivial. The uninitated might not appreciate how this is different from a distribution of a single data set; whereby the standard error = the standard devation / sqrt(n).

author: @jgray2718
text: So I know bootstrapping is a well-respected and useful technique, but I have never been able to shake the feeling that repeated sampling from a sample doesn't really tell you anything, and that it should be relatively easy to calculate the actual bootstrapped sampling distribution rather than just making an approximation of it; I get that nobody's actually using this on a sample of size 8, but is there really no calculation we can just do?  If I'm sampling with replacement my population size is effectively infinite, but consists only of a few discrete values.  If I'm calculating the sample mean each time, why does the CLT not apply?  Assuming a large enough sample and/or a normal enough original sample distribution, don't we know not only what the mean and standard deviation of the bootstrapped distribution will be, but also the bootstrapped sampling distribution itself?  It's also not clear to me why the bootstrapped distribution should tell you more about the population distribution than the original sample would, since the bootstrapped distribution is derived entirely from the sample.  Just in terms of what information can be gleaned from using the same numbers over and over it seems like you can't really be adding any new knowledge by sort of artificially repeating a sample, but without adding any actual new data.  Yes, if the sample is representative of the population you'll get something that looks like repeated samples, but if it's not, you won't.  And if it's in any way imperfectly representative of the population distribution, won't that imperfection be magnified by taking thousands of biased samples and pretending they're unbiased?  I mean, it's true that random sampling is unbiased over a large number of samples _from the population_ but any given sample is almost certainly biased at least a little bit, so using a single sample over and over should produce biased results, shouldn't it?  Anyway, I know the math behind bootstrapping exists, but I've never looked for it, so I'm sure this is fine.  It just feels very, I don't know, incestuous?

author: @vtphan2012
text: Another great video. This video explains how to do bootstrap, which is the easy part. The more difficult part is to understand why bootstrap works.  The conceptual challenge is that bootstrapping assumes that if we were to repeat an experiment, it would produce one of the outcomes we had observed.  This could be a huge assumption, depending on the applications.   Boot strapping does not add any new information to what has been observed.

author: @statquest
text: NOTE: A lot of people ask "What happens when the original collection of measurements is not representative of the underlying distribution?" It's important to remember that a confidence interval is not guaranteed to overlap the true, population mean. A 95% CI means that if we make a ton of CIs using the same method, 95% of them will overlap the true mean. This tells us that 5% of the time we'll be off. So yes, a sample that is totally bonkers is possible, but rare. Understanding this risk of making the wrong decision, and managing it, is what statistics is all about. Also, at 5:55 I say there are up to 8^8 combinations of observed values and possible means, but this assumes that order matters, and it doesn't. So 8^8 over counts the total number of useful combinations and the true number is 15 choose 8, which is 6435 (for details on this math, see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiset#Counting_multisets )  Support StatQuest by buying my book The StatQuest Illustrated Guide to Machine Learning or a Study Guide or Merch!!! https://statquest.org/statquest-store/

author: @auggieheschmeyer7333
text: Bootstrapping assumes that the data you are bootstrapping is a representative sample, correct? For instance, in the example you outline in the video, let's say that five people who felt better using the drug were five hand-selected rather than randomly selected participants. Bootstrapping their data would give us an inaccurate impression of what the true mean might be because of this bias, right?

author: @orzhovthief
text: That's totally biased : there's a hidden assumption that the original data is representative or valuable. So of course if your original data is corrupted, derived calculation will also be. Here the method show that by repeating random operations a sufficient number of time we get a gaussian distribution : well know and without any surprise. I'm sure there's a ton of "data scientist/analyst" that use this technique on a dayly basis on under sampled studies.  No wonder half data science is non reproductible ...
